localizedDescriptions.en: Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Record details about the rate and associated attributes for a pulse or heart beat.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The rate, measured in beats per minute.

annotations.comment: Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Method of monitoring blood gas measurements such as Spo2 and pTCO2 by indirect, currently non-invasive, means.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Measured via pulse oximetry, the saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood.

annotations.comment: spO2 is defined as the ratio of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO2) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO2 + deoxyhaemoglobin).

localizedDescriptions.en: The observed characteristics of spontaneous breathing as would commonly be recorded as part of a 'vital signs' examination.
Generic event.
Rate of respiration.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the whole body temperature of the person.
Any event.
The measured body temperature (as a surrogate for the whole body).

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation.  Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.
Default event.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer.
Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care.
Subjective observation of a physical or mental disturbance, experienced by an individual.
The symptom experienced by the subject of care.

annotations.comment: Symptom name should be coded with a terminology, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Information captured by the howRU™ patient-reported outcomes instrument.
Symptoms such as pain – includes all physical forms of discomfort such as breathlessness, itching, dizziness or nausea.
The subject is not affected at all.
The subject is only slighly affected.
The subject is considerably affected.
The subject is extremely affected.
Feeling low or worried – includes all psychological states, including anxiety, feeling low and depression.
The subject is not affected at all.
The subject is only slighly affected.
The subject is considerably affected.
The subject is extremely affected.

children.name: Limited in what I can do
children.localizedName: Limited in what I can do

localizedNames.en: Limited in what I can do

localizedDescriptions.en: Limited in what I can do – includes incapacity due to physical or psychological reasons, such as not being able to perform activities of daily living, or not being able to carry out leisure activities.
The subject is not affected at all.
The subject is only slighly affected.
The subject is considerably affected.
The subject is extremely affected.
Dependent on others – the need to rely on other people or equipment.
The subject is not affected at all.
The subject is only slighly affected.
The subject is considerably affected.
The subject is extremely affected.
An overall score combining the 4 individual ratings.
